results.title: Under one sky
results.creator_credit: Jennifer Kawaja and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The veiled women of the Middle East have provided a constant source of fascination for Western culture over the years. The hijab (veil) has come to represent a number of conflicting issues, namely the oppression of Muslim women, the notion of the exotic “other”, and the tensions existing between Eastern and Western values. This insightful and thought-provoking documentary focuses on a group of women in North America who choose to wear the hijab for reasons relating to identity, religion and politics. Rebelling against the fragmented images of women presented through the Western media, these women reveal the complex ideologies behind the veil while simultaneously throwing down a challenge to those - both from the East and West - who would try to oppress them.

results.title: Under night streets
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: A commentary on the people who work all night to keep London’s Underground on the move. Told with Cockney humour, it is the story of the care and thoroughness of night maintenance work.

results.title: Under new management
results.creator_credit: Tina Viljoen, Adam Symansky and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film is about the francization of Quebec that has taken place since the Parti Quebecois won power from the Liberals in 1976. It shows how the once powerful anglophone community is now questioning its very survival. It discusses some of the motivating forces behind Quebecois nationalism. The film concludes by asking if the Canadian nation can survive if neither of its major language groups is welcome in the territory of the other.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tina Viljoen, Adam Symansky and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Under my skin
results.creator_credit: Jacqueline Matisse, School of Film and Television and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: A succinct Australian claymation which explores the demise of a doomed relationship between a beautiful French poodle, Fifi, and a somewhat dejected looking flea, who has been given his marching orders in a most diplomatic fashion. (Awards: St Kilda Film Festival, 2001; the Vancouver Effects and Animation Festival, 1999 and various other international festivals)

results.title: Under Milk Wood
results.creator_credit: Andrew Sinclair, Jules Buck, Hugh French and Timon Films
results.brief_description: Based on the radio play by Dylan Thomas, this film weaves a tapestry of words around the lives and dreams of the inhabitants of the tiny Welsh village of Llareggub. Cast includes Richard Burton as the first voice, Elizabeth Taylor as Rosie Probert and Peter O’Toole as Captain Cat.

results.title: Under cover

results.brief_description: Marten McEachran might be a normal schoolkid, but he also leads another, secret life. These lives co-exist happily and McEachran recognises that it is both lives that make him who he is.

results.title: Undead
results.creator_credit: Peter Spierig, Michael Spierig, Imagine Entertainment (US) and Spierigfilm
results.brief_description: Australian twin filmmaking brothers, Michael and Peter Spierig, have written, produced and directed this, their first feature film. They have achieved their goal of creating a schlock splatter horror with a load of laughs but with a sci-fi alien plot twist that makes it stands out. What also stands out is the finish of the film as its low budget is not that evident in the final outcome. Fictional small Australian country town of Berkeley, renowned for its good fishing, is invaded by aliens that send strange meteors from space turning people into the undead - zombies. The local beauty contest winner Rene (Felicity Mason) is about to leave town but is prevented when her driver becomes victim to zombie attack. The local town loony, a tall silent bloke called Marion (Mungo McKay), comes to her aid with a three-barrelled custom-made rifle. Blood, gore, splatter and laughs aplenty ensue as our hapless heroes (including the swearing town cop and his rookie constable, Wayne and his pregnant girlfriend) go about surviving the onslaught of brain sucking zombies. The aliens appear on earth cleansing some folks with healing rain and they are then ascended to orbit the earth. The ending has the potential for a sequel and hopefully someone will give them the money! This is must see cult classic for those into the schlock/horror or low budget independent genre/s. Crew that deserve special mention are the make-up designer Steven Boyle, cinematographer Andrew Strahorn, composer Cliff Bradley and everyone that worked on the special effects, which includes the directors. (“The Making Of” in the extras is worth a look if you’re thinking of making a low budget feature!) Hopefully there will be more from The Spierig Brothers in the future. SOME SCENES MAY DISTURB.

results.title: Uncut
results.brief_description: This low budget experimental genre-bending exercise from Canadian director John Greyson revolves around the themes of censorship, circumcision and copyright. Greyson interweaves fiction and fact whilst commentating upon the vagaries of popular culture, with an examination of the history of censorship, raging against the conservatism of the era that does not recognise the importance of historical accuracy and truths. The fictional component of the film is set in Ottawa in 1979 and revolves around the fortunes of three Peters - one is writing a book against circumcision; the second is his typist who nurses an obsession with Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau; the third is a sinister presence who becomes intimately acquainted with the other two. The documentary component of the film (inter-cut with the fictional elements) concerns copyright laws and examines how such laws are homophobic and hamper creativity whilst protecting the rights and creative output of the rich and famous. Although this work is elliptical, it provides a fascinating cornucopia of issues from the perspective of a polemicist, presenting an irreverent and independent viewpoint about gay politics and mass culture. Cast includes Matthew Ferguson, Michael Achtman, Damon D’Oliveira.
